title: Employers added just 136K jobs in September while unemployment rate hits a new 50-year low
text:
CLOSE The National Bureau of Economic Research determines a recession occurs when “a significant decline in economic activity” lasts more than “a few months.” USA TODAY

Hiring slowed in September as employers added 136,000 jobs, doing little to ease recession concerns and at least opening the door to another Federal Reserve rate cut as early as this month.

The unemployment rate fell from 3.7% to 3.5%, the lowest since December 1969, the Labor Department said Friday.

Economists expected 145,000 job gains, according to a Bloomberg survey.

Partly offsetting the weak showing: Job gains for July and August were revised up by a total 45,000. July’s additions were upgraded from 159,000 to 166,000 and August’s from 130,000 168,000.

Average wages, however, fell.

Wall Street cheered the mixed report, which highlighted a falling unemployment rate but kept in play a possible Fed rate cut this month, which would be the third since July.

Investors bought both stocks and bonds. That demand pushed up the Dow Jones industrial average by 228 points, or nearly 1%, at midday. Bond prices, which move in the opposite direction of yields, rose. The yield on the 10-year Treasury bond was down marginally to 1.52%.

The jobs numbers were released amid mounting concerns that the economy may be heading toward a recession. A manufacturing index this week showed a contraction in activity for a second straight month in September and at the briskest pace in 10 years. Producers cited the toll taken by President Trump’s trade war with China and a sluggish global economy.

Of even greater concern is that the much larger service sector is also faltering. An index of activity among services firms revealed expansion last month but at the slowest pace in three years. The service sector makes up 80% of the economy and had been bolstered by steady consumer spending. But U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports are nudging up store prices and dampening retailers’ confidence.

"This is as good as it's likely to get until the trade war is resolved," Ian Shepherdson, an economist with Pantheon Macroeconomics, said of the September job gains in a note to clients.

FILE - In this June 21, 2019, file photo a now hiring sign is displayed to attract potential workers at a McDonald's restaurant in Moss Point, Miss. On Wednesday, July 31, payroll processor ADP reports on how many jobs its survey estimates U.S. companies added in July. (AP Photo/Rogelio V. Solis, File) (Photo: Rogelio V. Solis, AP)

Employment growth has slowed to an average monthly pace of 161,000 this year from 223,000 in 2018, though last year’s figures are expected to be revised down sharply.

Two main factors are crimping job gains.The low unemployment rate has made it tougher for businesses to find workers. And the economy has slowed as the effects of federal tax cuts and spending increases peter out and the trade war dents business confidence and investment.

In an effort to dodge a recession, the Fed has lowered its key interest rate twice since late July despite a still-solid economy. Some economists expect another rate cut at a Fed meeting late this month.

Wages dip

Average hourly earnings edged down 1 cent to $28.09, pushing down the annual gain from 3.2% to 2.9%.

Yearly pay increases began topping 3% in the second half of 2018 as employers bid up to attract fewer available workers, but haven’t gained further momentum. That has kept inflation subdued, providing the Fed another reason to reduce rates as early as this month.

Industries that are hiring

Businesses added just 114,000 jobs while federal, state and local governments added 22,000. Health care led the private-sector job gains with 41,000. Professional and business services added 34,000; leisure and hospitality, 21,000; and transportation and warehousing, 16,000.

Manufacturers lost 2,000 jobs in a sign the trade war and slowing global economy continue to take a toll. Retailers cut 11,000 jobs, partly reflecting a longer-term shift to online shopping.

Broader unemployment gauge falls

A wider measure of unemployment -- that includes part-time workers who want full-time jobs and discouraged Americans who have given up job searches, as well as the unemployed – fell from 7.2% to 6.9%, a 19-year low.

What it means

The September report was a mixed bag. A disappointing 136,000 jobs were added but totals for the prior two months were revised up by 45,000. And unemployment fell to a new 50-year low but wages slipped, nudging down annual pay increases to the slowest pace July 2018.

Pantheon’s Shepherdson said the report was good enough to keep the Fed from trimming rates this month, but Morgan Stanley said it likely gave the central bank enough evidence for another cut.

CLOSE Although U.S. employers added a modest 130,000 jobs in August, a sign that hiring has slowed, the White House stressed the positives in the report, especially wage gains and the re-entry of many workers into the labor market. (Sept. 6) AP
